CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: Figure 10 shows the AFM images of the polymer : PC71BM ( 1 : 5 wt % ) films , which were taken after removal of the Al electrode and after device fabrication. The Al electrode was removed by dipping the devices for 1 min in a mixed acid solution containing of 16 mL of concentrated phosphoric acid , 1 mL of concentrated hydrochloric acid , 1 mL of acetic acid , and 2 mL of D 2 O. The blend films showed almost equivalently measured smooth surfaces ( according to their root-mean-square ( rms ) roughness ) with small degrees of phase separation. The rms roughness of the active layers were 0.49 nm for PFDTBT , 0.44 nm for PFDTBT-10Per , 0.51 nm for PFD2TBT , and 0.50 nm for PFD2TBT-10Per , respectively. This result suggests that the morphologies of all the active films are very similar , so that such a property will not affect the J sc of the photovoltaic devices. Therefore , the improvement of PCE and J sc in the fabricated photovoltaic devices is derived from the enhanced π-π interaction between polymers that results from the introduction of perylene units . We introduced perylene units into PFDTBT and PFD2TBT to enhance the interchain π-π interaction. The optical and electrochemical properties of the synthesized copolymers showed were slight modification upon perylene addition. Interestingly , the field - effect mobility of the TFTs , using the polymers as the active layer increased with an increasing perylene content in the copolymers. The short circuit currents of the photovoltaic devices fabricated using the polymers as an electron donor , also increased as the perylene content in the copolymers increased , which is consistent with the field - effect mobility results of the polymers. We conclude that the introduction of perylene to the conjugated polymer chain enhances the π-π interaction between polymer chains and improves its charge - transport ability , leading to increases short circuit currents in the photovoltaic devices . Corresponding Author *E - mail : dohoonhwang @ pusan.ac.kr .

Let's think step by step.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PC71BM |
| PFDTBT |
| PFDTBT-10Per |
| PFD2TBT |
| PFD2TBT-10Per |
| perylene |

Note: "perylene" is not a specific material name, but rather a class of materials. In the context of the paragraph, it refers to the perylene units that were introduced into the polymers PFDTBT and PFD2TBT.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Material name" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PC71BM |
| PFDTBT |
| PFDTBT-10Per |
| PFD2TBT |
| PFD2TBT-10Per |

Note: The term "perylene" was removed from the list as it does not clearly refer to a specific material name, but rather a class of materials.

PV.content:

Paragraph: Figure 10 shows the AFM images of the polymer : PC71BM ( 1 : 5 wt % ) films , which were taken after removal of the Al electrode and after device fabrication. This result suggests that the morphologies of all the active films are very similar , so that such a property will not affect the J sc of the photovoltaic devices. Therefore , the improvement of PCE and J sc in the fabricated photovoltaic devices is derived from the enhanced π-π interaction between polymers that results from the introduction of perylene units . We introduced perylene units into PFDTBT and PFD2TBT to enhance the interchain π-π interaction. The optical and electrochemical properties of the synthesized copolymers showed were slight modification upon perylene addition. Interestingly , the field - effect mobility of the TFTs , using the polymers as the active layer increased with an increasing perylene content in the copolymers. We conclude that the introduction of perylene to the conjugated polymer chain enhances the π-π interaction between polymer chains and improves its charge - transport ability , leading to increases short circuit currents in the photovoltaic devices . Corresponding Author *E - mail : dohoonhwang @ pusan.ac.kr .

Let's think step by step.

| Property Value | Description |
| --- | --- |
| 16 mL | Volume of concentrated phosphoric acid |
| 1 mL | Volume of concentrated hydrochloric acid |
| 1 mL | Volume of acetic acid |
| 2 mL | Volume of D2O |
| 1 min | Time for which the devices were dipped in the acid solution |
| 0.49 nm | rms roughness of PFDTBT active layers |
| 0.44 nm | rms roughness of PFDTBT-10Per active layers |
| 0.51 nm | rms roughness of PFD2TBT active layers |
| 0.50 nm | rms roughness of PFD2TBT-10Per active layers |
| π-π interaction | Intermolecular interaction between polymer chains |
| field-effect mobility | Mobility of charge carriers in a polymer film under an electric field |
| short circuit currents | Currents flowing through a photovoltaic device under illumination |
| perylene content | Concentration of perylene units in the copolymers |
| 10Per | Concentration of perylene units in the copolymers (10% by weight) |

Note: The values in the "Property Value" column are presented as they appear in the original paragraph, without any unit conversions or modifications.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Value of material property" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Value".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Property Value | Description |
| --- | --- |
| 0.49 nm | rms roughness of PFDTBT active layers |
| 0.44 nm | rms roughness of PFDTBT-10Per active layers |
| 0.51 nm | rms roughness of PFD2TBT active layers |
| 0.50 nm | rms roughness of PFD2TBT-10Per active layers |

Note: The entities that do not clearly refer to "Value of material property" have been removed from the table. The remaining entities are the rms roughness values of the active layers of the different polymers, which are clearly material properties.
